Overview

The purpose of this project is to compile the information and materials necessary to resubmit a current plan for the BASF Malcom Facility.





BASF facility in Malcom, Iowa is subject to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions" found in Title 40 part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).   The facility is covered by the rule because it stores Toluene Diisocyanate, (20% Toluene-2,6-diisocyanate, 80-100% Toluene-2,4-diisocyanate)  in excess of the regulatory 10,000 pound threshold in the Malcom Warehouse and uses this chemical in processing polyurethane products.   Toluene Diisocyanate, (20% Toluene-2,6-diisocyanate, 80-100% Toluene-2,4-diisocyanate) are received in approved DOT drums, (55 gallon drums), and is used in polyurethane production.  The drums are moved from the warehouse to the processing area, Plant 1.  The quantity in Plant 1 will not exceed 10 drums at a time during processing.  The material will be stored in the Malcom warehouse at ambient temperature.   The maximum quantity in the warehouse will not exceed 100 drums or 55100 pounds. 



Accident History:

BASF Malcom has not had any releases from the process that resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, responses or restoration activities within the last 3 years of ownership.



Offsite Consequence Analysis:  Worst Case

Ambient air temperature at 102 deg F, 58% relative humidity, Stability class F, Release inside a building into containment. 



An offsite consequence analysis was conducted on a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario involving Toluene Diisocyanate, (20% Toluene-2,6-diisocyanate, 80-100% Toluene-2,4-diisocyanate). ALOHA was used to determine the worst-case release scenario using toluene-2, 4-diisocyanate and toluene-2,6-diisocyanate as the mixed isomer. 



An evaluation was completed which identified the worst case to be the bottom valve on Reactor 15 failed releasing a maximum of 5000 pounds of the

unspecified isomer in the containment pit inside Plant 1 center room.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint was determined to be 0.009 miles, retaining the spill to inside the building.   The population within the threat zone was determined to be approximately 15 people working inside the building.   There would be no threat to the residences or commercial/industrial within the boundary of the spill. 



Offsite Consequence Analysis:  Alternate Case

Ambient air temperature at 102 deg F, 58% relative humidity, Stability class F, Release inside a building, building considered containment, no drains to storm or sanitary. 





Two alternative release scenarios were examined. An alternative release scenario examined 1 -55 gallon drum being punctured in the Malcom Warehouse. Approximately 551 pounds of TDI unspecified isomers would be released inside an enclosed building.  The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint was determined 0.005 miles, retaining the spill to inside the building .  The population within the threat zone was determined to be approximately 15 people working inside the building.   There would be no threat to the residences or commercial/industrial within the boundary of the spill. 



 

The additional alternative release scenario examined 1-55 gallon drum being punctured in Plant 1 Processing area.  Approximately 551 pounds of TDI would be released inside an enclosed building.   The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint was determined to be 0.005 miles.  The population within the threat zone was determined to be approximately 15 people working in the building.  There would be no threat to the residences or commercial/industrial within the boundary of the spill.
